description: From Middle English leyser, from Anglo-Norman leisir, variant of Old French loisir (“to enjoy oneself”) (Modern French loisir survives as a noun), substantive use of a verb, from Latin licēre (“be permitted”). Displaced native Old English ǣmetta.

entries.meaning: Freedom provided by the cessation of activities.
Free time, time free from work or duties.
examples: The desire of leisure is much more natural than of business and care.

entries.meaning: Time at one's command, free from engagement; convenient opportunity; hence, convenience; ease.
